ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained in-depth knowledge on the ways that politics, including racial politics, influence the development of the carceral state and the political implications of policing and incarceration on highly policed and race-class marginalized communities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great course to write a senior essay in. At least this semester, the course was structured around a final paper (or for those writing it, a senior essay) for which there are several checkpoints through the semester to keep you on track. The workload is manageable, and the content is always well selected for good discussion in class. Professor Harris is also excellent, made the class really straightforward and enjoyable to be in.

The strengths are that the course materials and lectures with a broad through thorough survey of research on the dimensions and implications of the carceral state at federal, state, and local levels while also providing students with insightful knowledge about causal inference, research designs, and the limitations of research studies. Another strength is that Professor Harris is extremely accessible and provides clear expectations and feedback that help students improve their writing and research (i.e. outlining ways to construct a concise, clear, poignant thesis statement).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Professor Harris is awesome, she always makes discussion productive and engaging. The structure of the course (e.g. selecting your own dates for the response paper, submission of weekly discussion questions) makes it so that you stay engaged with the course material, but never feel particularly overwhelmed. A great course that teaches a lot about the criminal justice system as a whole, as well as broader institutions and historical trends which create the environment around crime, policing, and jailing that we see today.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The course expanded my knowledge on the politics and structural inequalities that that undergird the carceral state and the implications of carceral contact for highly policed individuals and their communities, which are low-income communities of color by and large.

extras.title: AFAM 244 01/PLSC 200 01 - Crime and Punishment in Cities
